content:
The desk will operate its usual schedule until Thursday April 18th 2130BST upon which the desk will close and remain closed for the entirety of Friday 19th April in observance of Good Friday with UK, EU and US markets all closed. 

The Service will resume on Sunday April 21st at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pac session and will run until Monday 22nd April at 0630BST at which point the service will halt due to the closure of EU and UK markets. The service will then resume at 1300BST for the beginning of the US session with US markets subject to a regular open.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 18 April 2019: Stocks advance on strong earnings, decent US data; EZ PMIs disappoint.
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar up, Treasuries up, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Soft EZ PMIs, decent US data, as traders head into the long weekend.

* AHEAD: Monday: Easter Monday. Tuesday: US & Eurozone Markit Flash PMIs, Eurozone Flash Consumer Confidence. Wednesday: BoC Interest Rate Decision, ECB Economic Bulletin. Thursday: BoJ Monetary Policy meeting, Riksbank & CBRT Interest Rate Decisions, US Durable Goods (Mar). Friday: Japanese Labour Market Report & Retail Sales, US GDP (Advance), Uni of Michigan (Final). Sunday: Spanish General Election. Click here for full week ahead preview.

* US RETAIL SALES: Came in better than expected, rising 1.6% M/M in March, bouncing back from the -0.2% M/M reading in February. Gasoline prices and vehicle sales underpinned the headline, though core retail sales also rose firmly. “The strong March performance indicates that the early Q1 weakness in consumer spending was temporary, and that spending is poised to rebound just under 3% in Q2, up from around 0.6% growth in Q1,” Oxford Economics said. “The latest data continue to illustrate the extreme degree of volatility at the start of the year, in part related to the government shutdown, and underscore the importance of focussing on underlying trends.” The consultancy also argues that the rebound bodes well for the domestic US outlook, and is well supported by labour market fundamentals; it also dispels “misguided” concerns that the US economy is slipping into recession, the consultancy argues.

* US BUSINESS INVENTORIES: Came in slightly short of expectations at 0.3%, following the 1.6% gain across December and January – the largest two month gain since 2011. The inventory to sales ratio held at 1.39 for the third straight month. Analysts believe that inventories will now make a positive contribution to GDP growth in Q1 (see week in focus for full preview of next week’s advance GDP print for Q1). “Since part of the inventory build-up earlier this year was likely involuntary amid cooler domestic demand and softer global activity, we expect businesses to shrink relative inventory levels in the coming months,” Oxford Economics believes.

* US INITIAL JOBLESS CLAIMS: A new cyclical low at 192k (-5k), against expectations of a rise. It is worth noting that this was also the survey week for the April nonfarm payrolls report, and Barclays says the initial jobless claims and continuing claims data points to healthy labour market conditions.

* CANADIAN RETAIL SALES: The 0.8% M/M rise in retail sales was slightly better than expected, but the data wasn't as good as the headline suggests, Scotiabank said. "Much of the gain of 0.8% was due to higher prices, but volumes were still up by a modest 0.2% M/M," adding that "regional effects were pronounced and very cold temperatures in western Canada may have depressed sales volumes more than would have otherwise been the case." Retail sales have been going sideways since last Spring, the bank notes, with two factors in play: "brought forward consumption into the period of prior stimulus (child benefit cheques), and combined rate/housing effects. Solid job and wage gain trends could provide a constructive backdrop for future expectations after we get through the adjustment phase especially if pent-up weather-related demand exists." Retail sales volumes in Q1 are tracking around 1.1% Q/Q according to Scotia's data, and lower in seasonally adjusted terms after the 0.3% decline in Q4. However, this is unlikely to worry the BOC: "Recall that back in the January MPR before the BoC did its statement changes in March, they had forecast Q1 GDP growth of 0.8%. We’re probably still tracking at or north of 1%. Nowcasts nevertheless await March data that will further inform estimates."

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD 0.24 HIGHER AT USD 64.00/BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD 0.35 HIGHER AT USD 71.97/BBL. Crude markets closed the week essentially where they started it, consolidating around YTD highs in a lack of major updates on supply. “Macroeconomic signals were mixed, with strong numbers in the US, but weakness in Europe that is contributing to a stronger US dollar, limiting market sentiment at least for the day,” analysts at Citigroup comment. “Light book squaring ahead of the Good Friday holiday weekend and the May WTI contract expiration to follow on Monday,” are other factors playing into the recent volatility of the market, Citi’s analyst highlight. Thursday’s main supply update came out of Libya, where it announced its El Waha oil field will cut its output by 124k BPD in early May, leaving it running at 176k BPD; the market is still pricing in a geopolitical risk factor for Libya where fears still remain of its civil conflict putting a halt to its oil exports. The Baker Hughes rig count for the week showed total rigs down by 10 at 1012, oil rigs down by 8 at 825 and gas rigs down by 2 at 187; the cut in rigs comes after two consecutive weeks of rig count rises.

* SPX +0.2% at 2905, NDX +0.1% at 7690, DJI +0.4% at 26561. SECTORS: Communications 0.0%, Cons Discretionary -0.1%, Cons Staples -0.0%, Energy -0.5%, Financials -0.2%, Healthcare +0.1%, Industrials +1.1%, Materials +0.1%, Tech +0.3%, Telecoms +0.1%, Utilities +0.0%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Biotech and Pharma names, including Merck & Co (MRK), Pfizer (PFE), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), AbbVie Inc (ABBV) fell as the healthcare rout spread. However, United Health (UNH) were lifted after unconfirmed reports emerged that Dan Loeb’s Third Point had reportedly taken a ‘significant share’ in the health insurance provider. American Express (AXP) rose after the earnings matched expectations and affirmed their outlook for 2019. Travelers (TRV) gained after the insurer beat analyst expectations, improving bottom line earnings on a YY basis and announced an increase in quarterly dividend. Honeywell International (HON) shares reached all-time highs after the industrial conglomerate beat top and bottom-line earnings forecasts. Kinder Morgan (KMI) fell after the firm missed revenue expectations, despite raising quarterly dividend. Union Pacific (UNP) traded higher after the firm’s net profit rose despite lower revenues. United Rentals (URI) traded higher after the industrial equipment rental co. first-quarter earnings beat analyst expectations. Constellation Brands (STZ) shares rose after the brand announced the sale of part of its wine business, which may give the firm the flexibility to increase its stake in CBD product maker Canopy Growth (CGC), whose shares also rose. Blackstone (BX) traded higher after the company announced it would move from a partnership structure to a corporation, a move that will allow the firm to reduce tax liabilities.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 9 TICKS HIGHER AT 123-4+. Yields fell across the curve on Thursday, taking their cues from Bunds in the European morning, after weak Eurozone PMIs reinforced concerns about downside risks outweighing upside risks. The complex struggled to sell-off after jobless claims data that fell to new cyclical lows, as well as a generally upbeat retail sales report. Meanwhile, business inventories gives rise to hopes that they will positively contribute to GDP in Q1. However, ahead of the long-weekend, trade petered out as the Europeans left for the week, and at settlement, major curve spreads were slightly narrower.

*Weekly FX Wrap: King Dollar takes the throne ahead of Easter

* USD: The Dollar and DXY are looking to end the holiday-shortened week on a strong note, with the latter having fluctuated in a 96.800-97.400 weekly range. US-China developments did little to sway the buck, with the latest reports signalling compromise on both sides and a potential deal signing in May. The USD felt some pressure following the upbeat Chinese data which aided USD/CNH to reach levels close to 6.6800 to the downside from a high of 6.7124 (that day). DXY recouped those losses during Thursday’s trade amid the demise of the EUR, sparked by overall disappointing EZ PMIs. A final bout of demand was observed amid optimistic US March retail sales, with Fed’s Bostic (non-voter, dove) left on the docket ahead of the Easter break. Looking ahead, next week sees the release of US Durable goods for March alongside Q1 GDP advanced.

* EUR, GBP: Overall a downbeat week for the Single Currency with EUR/USD poised to end the shortened week closer to the lower end of the week’s 1.1238-1.1324 range. A bulk of the Euro’s weekly losses are as a result of dismal PMIs (again) which took the EUR/USD back below the 1.1300 level (and 50 DMA at 1.1294) before the pair dipped below 1.1250. Similarly, Sterling is poised end European trade on the backfoot as Brexit bedlam takes a back-seat (for now) with UK parliament on recess. The currency shrugged off employment data and started retreating from weekly highs earlier in the week after UK press reported that cross-party talks are coming to a standstill (although later denied by UK labour spokesman). GBP/USD felt another bout of weakness after disappointing March inflation figures wherein headline missed expectations by 0.1ppt. Cable looks to end the session around the 1.30 level after having breached its 50 DMA (1.3028) mid-week, having traded in a 1.2993-1.3080 band.

* AUD, NZD: It’s been a rough week for the Antipodeans, more-so the Kiwi amid gloomy NZ inflation figures which have prompted money markets to increase the chances of an RBNZ OCR cut to 50% (vs. Prev. 25%). NZD/USD is poised to end the session closer to the bottom of this week’s 0.6665-6761 range, having breached its 50 DMA to the downside at 0.6761 ahead of next week’s Kiwi Trade Balance. Elsewhere, the Aussie traded choppy for most of the week and is set to end the week in negative territory after the China data gains were offset by the overall USD strength. Furthermore, less pessimistic jobs data provided the Aussie with some short-live strength in which AUD/USD retested the 0.7200 level to the upside. All-in-all, AUD/USD is poised to end this week’s trade marginally in the red ahead of next week’s inflation figures where the street looks for the headline Y/Y to ease from 1.8% to 1.5%, after undershooting the RBA’s target band of 2-3% in 2018. The lack of price pressure mainly emanates from subdued wage growth, trouble in the housing market, retail competition and lethargic consumer spending. Hence, Westpac takes a slightly more pessimistic stance and expects the headline Y/Y figure to print at 1.4% due to receding oil prices alongside a “seasonally soft quarter”.

* CAD: Again, set to end trade in the red vs. the Buck after an initial hit from BoC’s Spring Business Outlook Survey as the headline index turned slightly negative whilst the snapshot is for a moderation form high levels of domestic and foreign demand across a number of regions. The Loonie largely shrugged off a miss in Canadian manufacturing sales as the currency, at the time, was buoyed by firmer energy prices, whilst a pickup in Canadian headline inflation (1.9% vs. Prev. 1.5% Y/Y) bolstered the CAD in the immediate aftermath. Nonetheless, Thursday’s bout of USD strength pushed the CAD back into the red for the week. USD/CAD is set to end EU trade closer to the top of a 1.3275-3400 range ahead of next week’s BoC rate decision (widely touted to stand pat on rates), BoC’s Governor Poloz and First Deputy Governor Wilkin’s speech post-decision.

* CHF, JPY: The Swiss Franc is set to notch a third week in the red with this week’s move vs. the EUR in a 1.1320-1.1420 parameter. EUR/CHF briefly breached its 50 DMA to the upside ahead of its 100 DMA at 1.1447. The pair is set to end EU trade just off highs amid the weaker EUR. Meanwhile, USD/JPY is poised to end the week marginally in the red, having fluctuated within a relatively narrow 111.80-112.20 band this week. Thursday’s cautious sentiment helped the pair fall below the 112.00 level and the 200 WMA at 111.95 ahead of Thursday’s BoJ rate decision which will include the Inflation Outlook report which will also take the first look into FY 2021, with sources stating that the Central Bank are to project FY 21 inflation above 1.5% but short of its 2% target, and FY 19 growth and inflation forecast are expected to be cut.

* TRY: Another week, another weaker Lira amid concern surrounding the CBRT’s foreign-currency reserves amid reports that the Central Bank boosted reserve with a few billion dollars of borrowed cash. Thus, investors and traders are questioning the country’s ability to defend itself in a currency crisis. USD/TRY is set to head into the long Easter weekend closer to the top of this week’s 5.7090-8515 band.

PRIMER: US Treasury to release Semi-Annual Report to Congress on International Economic and Exchange Rate Policies
content: The US Treasury's semiannual FX monitoring will be released in April, and identified countries that "merit close attention to their currency practices and macroeconomic policies," and country's that will make this naughty list will have to have two of the following three characteristics: a trade surplus with the US which is larger than USD 20bln; a current account surplus greater than 3%/GDP; net FX purchases by the central bank which are larger than 2%/GDP and persistent FX intervention (defined by buying currency in 8 of the 12 months covered by the report). China currently meets just one of these criteria (trade surplus with the US). While there is no direct consequence if a country is added to the list, the report will be submitted to Congress, and penalties and/or sanctions could follow; it would also give US President Trump ammunition to continue his hawkish trade policy. Currently the list comprises of China, India, South Korea, Switzerland, Germany, Japan.; it is unlikely that the US will take this opportunity to label any of these countries currency manipulators in this report (Japan and Taiwan come close, though), instead, there is a chance that India and Switzerland could be removed from the naughty list in the April 2019 report, given the former now only breaches one of the criteria (vs two in April 2018) now, and both have reduced FX interventions.

subject: Notice: Easter Desk Schedule
content:
The desk will operate its usual schedule until Thursday April 18th 2130BST upon which the desk will close and remain closed for the entirety of Friday 19th April in observance of Good Friday with UK, EU and US markets all closed. 

The Service will resume on Sunday April 21st at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pac session and will run until Monday 22nd April at 0630BST at which point the service will halt due to the closure of EU and UK markets. The service will then resume at 1300BST for the beginning of the US session with US markets subject to a regular open.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 18th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European indices [Euro Stoxx +0.3%] have traded choppily this morning, largely recovering from the poor PMIs
  • On the trade front the Chinese Commerce Ministry states that new progress has been made in agreeing the text for a US-China trade deal
  • Looking ahead US PMI (Flash), US Retail Sales, US Initial Jobless Claims & Business Inventories, US Philly Fed Business Index, Fed’s Bostic,
  • Earnings: Phillip Morris, Union Pacific, American Express

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were softer with the region tentative ahead of Easter closures and following a lacklustre performance on Wall St where a continued slump across the healthcare sector weighed across the major indices. ASX 200 (Unch) was choppy with the index initially dragged lower as health stocks tracked the underperformance of their counterparts stateside, although the index later recovered amid strength in miners and energy names following quarterly updates from the likes of Fortescue Metals, Santos and Woodside Petroleum. Meanwhile, Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) was weighed by a firmer currency, while Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) also traded subdued despite further liquidity efforts by the PBoC, as hopes for a RRR cut fade and as Hong Kong participants took risk off the table ahead of a 4-day closure. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with prices supported by the cautiousness in the region and amid mild gains in T-notes, while today’s enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs also attracted greater demand.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6911 (Prev. 6.7110)

PBoC is reportedly unlikely to lower RRR in the short-term after recent liquidity injections and MLF announcement, while better than expected Q1 data also means there is less pressure for a RRR cut. (China Securities Journal)

BoK kept the 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.75% as expected with the decision made unanimously. BoK said South Korea economy to grow mid-2% level this year and hover below prior projections but won't significantly diverge from potential level, while it added that exports are to recover gradually. (Newswires)

US

There has been new progress in agreeing on the text for a US-China trade deal, according to the Chinese Commerce Ministry (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea Leader Kim reportedly oversaw the test of a new tactical guided weapon. (KCNA) Subsequently, North Korea states that if the US does not get rid of the root cause of its nuclear programme, then no one can predict how the situation will turn out, adding that it does not want US Secretary of State Pompeo to be their dialogue. (KCNA)

An armed group has attacked an air base in Southern Libya, according to sources; the air base is controlled by Eastern Commander Haftar. (Newswires)

Magnitude 6.1 earthquake strikes Taiwan which reportedly shook buildings in Taipei. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Conservative MP Blunt has begun collecting names for a no-confidence vote against the Speaker Bercow, as the speaker is no longer impartial. (Guardian/Times)

A potential technological solution the to Irish border could be more than a decade away and in all likelihood is a very expensive prospect, according to a Home Office Document. (Sky)

UK Retail Sales MM (Mar) 1.1% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. 0.4%, Rev. 0.6%).

French Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Apr) 49.6 vs. Exp. 50 (Prev. 49.7)

- French Markit Services Flash PMI (Apr) 50.5 vs. Exp. 49.8 (Prev. 49.1)

- French Markit Comp Flash PMI (Apr) 50.0 vs. Exp. 49.7 (Prev. 48.9)

German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Apr) 44.5 vs. Exp. 45 (Prev. 44.1)

- German Markit Services Flash PMI (Apr) 55.6 vs. Exp. 55.1 (Prev. 55.4)

- German Markit Composite Flash PMI (Apr) 52.1 vs. Exp. 51.7 (Prev. 51.4)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Apr) 47.8 vs. Exp. 47.9 (Prev. 47.5)

- EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Apr) 52.5 vs. Exp. 53.2 (Prev. 53.3)

- EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Apr) 51.3 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.6)

EQUITIES

Major European indices began the day largely unchanged, but have since traded choppy [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%] with bourses mixed in spite of further optimistic US-China headlines, as markets are weighed on by broader risk sentiment following the poor PMIs out of the EZ. Sectors have followed a similar transition from flat to relatively mixed this morning, although the consumer staples sector (+1.1%) is significantly outperforming its peers. Buoyed by sector heavyweight Nestle (+1.1%) after a sales update, where they beat on Q1 revenue and affirmed FY19 sales towards 2020 target levels and Unilever (+3.5%) who have confirmed progress towards FY expectations. Other notable movers this morning include Osram Licht (-3.7%) who are trading at the bottom of the Stoxx 600 after reports that Carlyle & Bain are losing confidence regarding a bid for the Co. Kering (-3.6%) are in the red post earnings in-spite of beating on Q1 revenue and reporting LFL increases in Gucci & YSL, with some pre-market commentary citing the potential for downside on the sales increase not perceived as being large enough.

Taiwan Semiconductor (2330 TT) reported Q1 net TWD 61.4bln vs. Exp. TWD 64.6bln, operating profit TWD 64.3bln vs. Exp. TWD 70.4bln. Co. guides Q2 revenue USD 7.55-7.65bln vs. Exp. USD 7.63bln. (Newswires)

FX

EUR - Not the best day for the EUR as it tumbled to the bottom of the G8 performers following dismal manufacturing flash readings from France, Germany and in turn, the EZ. The single currency initially experienced some volatility at the release of the French metrics, before Germany’s miss brought the first wave of material downside, later exacerbated by the disappointing EZ numbers. All-in-all, EUR/USD gave up the 1.1300 handle and fell below its 50 DMA at 1.1294 before briefly breaching the psychological 1.1250. The pair currently resides just above 1.1250, having thus far traded within a 1.1245-1305 range.

USD - On the front-foot amidst the demise of the EUR post-PMIs as the DXY marches on above the 97.000 level from an intraday low of 96.950 (high 97.333). The index did little overnight and mostly traded sideways due to thinned holiday volume alongside a lack of catalysts. The Buck will be eyeing the slew of US data in the form of weekly jobless claims, Philly Fed, retail sales and Markit PMIs later in the session.

GBP - A victim of the post-PMI Dollar strength after Sterling tumbled in tandem with the EUR to an intraday low, although the Pound felt some reprieve following optimistic retail sales, boosted by weather. GBP/USD currently rests below its 50 WMA at 1.3033 at the bottom of today’s 1.3010-1.3053 with potential stops just below the round figure.

AUD - Aussie jobs data did little to provide any material move for the currency, although showed an employment change of 25.7k, a jump from last month’s 4.6k, surpassing expectations of 12.0k, whilst the unemployment rate ticked up to 5.0% from 4.9%, as expected. Westpac argues that due to the conflicting signals from a strengthening labour market against weak GDP, the RBA is seemingly putting more weight on employment from a policy perspective. The analysts add that “slow growth will eventually weigh on employment growth. On this basis, along with inflation remaining low, we continue to forecast cash rate cuts in August and November”. AUD/USD saw a knee-jerk higher to test 0.7200 before most of its gains. The aforementioned Dollar strength then sent to AUD back down to fresh session lows after trading within a 0.7160-.7200 thus far ahead of its 100 DMA at 0.7140. Note: AUD/USD sees USD 1.1bln in options expiring at strike 0.7175 at today’s NY cut.

SEK - The marked G10 underperformer amid the release of dreary unemployment numbers wherein the rate rose to 7.1% although it was expected to be maintained at 6.6%. As such, SEK failed to reap the benefits of the EUR’s weakness as EUR/SEK spiked higher to briefly breach 10.50 to the upside as before stabilising above its 50 DMA at 10.4841.

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Flash PMIs fail to resurrect on Easter weekend - 18th April 2019
content:

EQUITIES

Major European indices began the day largely unchanged, but have since traded choppy [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%] with bourses mixed in spite of further optimistic US-China headlines, as markets are weighed on by broader risk sentiment following the poor PMIs out of the EZ. Sectors have followed a similar transition from flat to relatively mixed this morning, although the consumer staples sector (+1.1%) is significantly outperforming its peers. Buoyed by sector heavyweight Nestle (+1.1%) after a sales update, where they beat on Q1 revenue and affirmed FY19 sales towards 2020 target levels and Unilever (+3.5%) who have confirmed progress towards FY expectations. Other notable movers this morning include Osram Licht (-3.7%) who are trading at the bottom of the Stoxx 600 after reports that Carlyle & Bain are losing confidence regarding a bid for the Co. Kering (-3.6%) are in the red post earnings in-spite of beating on Q1 revenue and reporting LFL increases in Gucci & YSL, with some pre-market commentary citing the potential for downside on the sales increase not perceived as being large enough.

FX

EUR - Not the best day for the EUR as it tumbled to the bottom of the G8 performers following dismal manufacturing flash readings from France, Germany and in turn, the EZ. The single currency initially experienced some volatility at the release of the French metrics, before Germany’s miss brought the first wave of material downside, later exacerbated by the disappointing EZ numbers. All-in-all, EUR/USD gave up the 1.1300 handle and fell below its 50 DMA at 1.1294 before briefly breaching the psychological 1.1250. The pair currently resides just above 1.1250, having thus far traded within a 1.1245-1305 range.

USD - On the front-foot amidst the demise of the EUR post-PMIs as the DXY marches on above the 97.000 level from an intraday low of 96.950 (high 97.333). The index did little overnight and mostly traded sideways due to thinned holiday volume alongside a lack of catalysts. The Buck will be eyeing the slew of US data in the form of weekly jobless claims, Philly Fed, retail sales and Markit PMIs later in the session.

GBP - A victim of the post-PMI Dollar strength after Sterling tumbled in tandem with the EUR to an intraday low, although the Pound felt some reprieve following optimistic retail sales, boosted by weather. GBP/USD currently rests below its 50 WMA at 1.3033 at the bottom of today’s 1.3010-1.3053 with potential stops just below the round figure.

AUD - Aussie jobs data did little to provide any material move for the currency, although showed an employment change of 25.7k, a jump from last month’s 4.6k, surpassing expectations of 12.0k, whilst the unemployment rate ticked up to 5.0% from 4.9%, as expected. Westpac argues that due to the conflicting signals from a strengthening labour market against weak GDP, the RBA is seemingly putting more weight on employment from a policy perspective. The analysts add that “slow growth will eventually weigh on employment growth. On this basis, along with inflation remaining low, we continue to forecast cash rate cuts in August and November”. AUD/USD saw a knee-jerk higher to test 0.7200 before most of its gains. The aforementioned Dollar strength then sent to AUD back down to fresh session lows after trading within a 0.7160-.7200 thus far ahead of its 100 DMA at 0.7140. Note: AUD/USD sees USD 1.1bln in options expiring at strike 0.7175 at today’s NY cut.

SEK - The marked G10 underperformer amid the release of dreary unemployment numbers wherein the rate rose to 7.1% although it was expected to be maintained at 6.6%. As such, SEK failed to reap the benefits of the EUR’s weakness as EUR/SEK spiked higher to briefly breach 10.50 to the upside as before stabilising above its 50 DMA at 10.4841.

subject: Notice: Easter Desk Schedule
content:
The desk will operate its usual schedule until Thursday April 18th 2130BST upon which the desk will close and remain closed for the entirety of Friday 19th April in observance of Good Friday with UK, EU and US markets all closed. 

The Service will resume on Sunday April 21st at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pac session and will run until Monday 22nd April at 0630BST at which point the service will halt due to the closure of EU and UK markets. The service will then resume at 1300BST for the beginning of the US session with US markets subject to a regular open.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

18th April 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were softer with the region tentative ahead of Easter closures and following a lacklustre performance on Wall St where a continued slump across the healthcare sector weighed across the major indices. ASX 200 (Unch) was choppy with the index initially dragged lower as health stocks tracked the underperformance of their counterparts stateside, although the index later recovered amid strength in miners and energy names following quarterly updates from the likes of Fortescue Metals, Santos and Woodside Petroleum. Meanwhile, Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) was weighed by a firmer currency, while Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) also traded subdued despite further liquidity efforts by the PBoC, as hopes for a RRR cut fade and as Hong Kong participants took risk off the table ahead of a 4-day closure.

FTSE

Segro (SGRO LN) – Co. added GBP 21mln of rental income in Q1 due to a surge in online shopping which boosted demand for warehouse space. Q1 net debt GBP 2.2bln vs. Prev. GBP 2.7bln. Q1 vacancy rate 4.4% vs. Prev. 5.2% Co. currently has 44 projects under construction, expected to generate GBP 57mln of annualised rent. Co. states that business has continued to perform strongly during Q1. (The Times/Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Wirecard (WDI GY) – The FT rejected allegations against its journalist accused of attempting to manipulate Co’s share price after the German financial regulator filed a criminal complaint against two FT journalists. (The Telegraph)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Sartorius (SRT GY) – Group revenue +16.8%, order intake +16.6%, Earnings margin +26.2% for Q1. Co. confirms FY guidance. Underlying EBITDA EUR 114mln, +28.7%. EPS EUR 0.71 vs. Prev. EUR 0.54. (Newswires)

Osram Licht (OSR GY) – Carlyle and Bain are said to be losing confidence regarding a bid for the Co. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

 

CAC

Schneider Electric (SU FP) – Co. Q1 rev. EUR 6.31bln vs. Exp. EUR 6.20bln, Co. organic sales increased by 5.9% Y/Y and affirms FY19 organic growth, organic Adj. EBITA and EBITA margin. FX impact on FY19 revenues is estimated at being between EUR 300-400mln, estimated impact on FY19 on adj. EBITDA margin could be around -10bps. (Newswires)

Pernod Ricard (RI FP) – Q3 sales EUR 2.003bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.0bln, +2.5%. Co. targets FY 18/19 underlying operating profit growth of 8% vs. Forecast. 6-8%. Q4 is to be impacted in China by inventory management of Martell Cognac in order to ensure growth sustainability. Co. sees a 50bps organic increase in profit from recurring operations margin in FY 18/19. (Newswires)

Kering (KER FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 3.79bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.70bln, LFL sales +17.4 Y/Y, Gucci sales LFL +20.0%, YSL sales LFL +17.5% and Bottega Veneta LFL sales -8.9%. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Edenred (EDEN FP) – Co. Q1 rev. EUR 383mln vs. Prev. EUR 332mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Sartorius Stedim Biotech (DIM FP) - Co. Q1 EBITDA EUR 98.1mln vs. Exp. EUR 88.6mln, rev. EUR 381.3mln vs. Exp. EUR 315.0mln. (Newswires)

Getlink (GET FP) – Q1 revenues +5% to EUR 254.4mln, passenger traffic slightly decreased in Q1. Group confirms EBITDA forecast to 2022. (Newswires)

Bollore (BOL FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 5.69bln vs. Prev. EUR 5.33bln. revenue +4% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Klepierre (LI FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 330.7mln vs. Prev. EUR 331.5mln. total gross rental income EUR 311.2mln vs. Prev. EUR 310.0mln. Shopping centres net rental income of EUR 265mln, +3.0% on a LFL basis. Co reaffirms 2019 outlook. (Newswires)

Euronext (ENX FP) – Co. affirms FY19 OPEX, with low-single digit growth. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Chip makers – Taiwan Semiconductor (2330 TT) reported Q1 net TWD 61.4bln vs. Exp. TWD 64.6bln, operating profit TWD 64.3bln vs. Exp. TWD 70.4bln. Co. guides Q2 revenue USD 7.55-7.65bln vs. Exp. USD 7.63bln. (Newswires)

Saipem (SPM IM) – Q1 revenue EUR 2.16bln. Q1 net EUR 21mln vs. Exp. EUR 27.9mln Y/Y. Q1 adj. EBITDA EUR 274mln. Co. sees FY19 revenues around EUR 9bln, adj. EBITDA margin in excess of 10%. Co. confirms their 2019 guidance. Regarding the South Stream Settlement the Co. expects to complete the negotiations or an amicable settlement of arbitration in the near future. (Newswires)

Repsol (RES SM) – Co. are said to have halted an oil swap agreement with Venezuela’s PDVSA due to the country’s tensions with the US. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

Underlying EPS in constant currencies & capital efficiencies are expected to increase, and portfolio management is on track. Co. states that the US and China maintained good momentum(Newswires)

content:

  • Asian indices are weaker as the region follows the subdued lead from Wall St. and ahead of a long weekend
  • Reports suggest US & China have set a tentative trade talks timeline; with a deal potentially to be signed as early as late May
  • Looking ahead, French, German, EZ, & US PMI (Flash) UK & US Retail Sales, US Initial Jobless Claims & Business Inventories, US Philly Fed Business Index, Fed’s Bostic, Supply from France
  • Earnings: Phillip Morris, Union Pacific, HoneyWell, PPG, American Express, Saipem

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were softer with the region tentative ahead of Easter closures and following a lacklustre performance on Wall St where a continued slump across the healthcare sector weighed across the major indices. (-0.2%) also traded subdued despite further liquidity efforts by the PBoC, as hopes for a RRR cut fade and as Hong Kong participants took risk off the table ahead of a 4-day closure. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with prices supported by the cautiousness in the region and amid mild gains in T-notes, while today’s enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs also attracted greater demand.

 

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6911 (Prev. 6.7110)

 

PBoC is reportedly unlikely to lower RRR in the short-term after recent liquidity injections and MLF announcement, while better than expected Q1 data also means there is less pressure for a RRR cut. (China Securities Journal)

US President Trump said China trade deal moving along nicely, while he suggested we will be hearing about China trade deal shortly and has a feeling the trade deal will be successful. In related news, reports suggested US and China have set a tentative timeline for next round of trade talks with USTR Lighthizer said to possibly to travel to Beijing during April 29th week, while the sides could sign a deal perhaps as early as late May. (WSJ)

BoK kept the 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.75% as expected with the decision made unanimously. BoK said South Korea economy to grow mid-2% level this year and hover below prior projections but won't significantly diverge from potential level, while it added that exports are to recover gradually. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Conservative MP Blunt has begun collecting names for a no-confidence vote against the Speaker Bercow, as the speaker is no longer impartial. (Guardian/Times)

 

A potential technological solution the to Irish border could be more than a decade away and in all likelihood is a very expensive prospect, according to a Home Office Document. (Sky)

 

FX

 

In FX markets, the DXY was stable and just about held on to the 97.00 level as most its major counterparts traded uneventful ahead of the upcoming holiday closures. EUR/USD was stuck near the 1.1300 level where it had meandered throughout the week and where a large option expiry of EUR 1.4bln is also located for today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD was uneventful as the 2-week parliament recess allowed the pair a breather from the Brexit-related chaos. USD/JPY softened amid the subdued risk tone but with downside limited as the 112.00 level continued to provide a magnet for price action, while antipodeans were relatively flat despite initial upside in AUD/USD following better than expected jobs data. The beat in headline Employment Change which was solely fuelled by Full-Time workers, pushed AUD/USD to within a whisker of the 0.7200 handle, where it then met resistance as some were also kept wary by the rise in the Unemployment Rate which was one of the conditions the RBA had recently outlined for a potential rate cut. Elsewhere, NZD/USD was quiet with interpolated OIS now pricing around 50% chance of a RBNZ rate cut next month vs. about 25% on Tuesday, although TD Securities suggested the recent CPI data was not a trigger for the RBNZ to ease next month and they also see a 'solid' floor at 0.6700 for the currency.

Australian Employment Change (Mar) 25.7k vs. Exp. 12.0k (Prev. 4.6k). (Newswires) Australian Full Time Employment (Mar) 48.3k (Prev. -7.3k) Australian Unemployment Rate (Mar) 5.0% vs. Exp. 5.0% (Prev. 4.9%) Australian Participation Rate (Mar) 65.7% vs. Exp. 65.6% (Prev. 65.6%) 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were uneventful overnight with WTI crude futures flat below the USD 64.00/bbl level after the prior day’s mild losses despite the surprise draw in DoE headline crude inventories, which was narrower than the headline draw in Tuesday’s API report. Recent comments from Russian Energy Novak also expressed caution regarding the extension of OPEC+ cuts as he said that it was too early to speak about preferable options for the output deal and will need to see how the market situation develops. Elsewhere, gold trickled further below the USD 1300/oz level to print a fresh YTD low, not helped by a stable DXY which remained above 97.00, while copper suffered from the risk averse tone across the region.

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

North Korea Leader Kim reportedly oversaw the test of a new tactical guided weapon. (KCNA)

 

US National Security Advisor Bolton said the US has imposed new sanctions on Venezuela's central bank to restrict US transactions and prohibit access to the USD. (Newswires)

 

 

US

Yields were slightly lower at settlement, paring the bear-steepening seen in early trade after an encouraging slate of China data, which stoked risk sentiment. There was some pause after it was officially confirmed that Germany cut its growth projection (the second time in months). However, the narrower trade balance saw sellers return. After the European close, action was slower as traders began eyeing the long weekend, and there were reports of profit-taking. Stocks couldn’t sustain the pre-market risk-on, and accordingly, Treasuries found demand in US trade. At settlement, major curve spreads were a touch steeper. US T-note futures (M9) settle 1 tick higher at 122-27+

Fed Beige Book said the US economy expanded at a slight-to-moderate pace in March and early April. Fed districts said growth continued at a similar pace as in the previous report and a few reported some strengthening, while employment continued to increase nationwide in which 9 districts reported modest or moderate growth and the others reported slight growth. Furthermore, reports on manufacturing activity were favourable but many Fed district contacts noted trade-related uncertainty. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (voter, neutral) said falling core inflation is a concern if it leads to falling expectations about future inflation, but also commented that he expects economy to do better in Q2 compared to first part of the year. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (non-voter, dove) repeated view for at most one hike for 2019 and one in 2020, while he commented he is keeping an eye on yield curve but noted inversion is not an absolute predictor of economic downturns. (Newswires)

Herman Cain said he will not withdraw from consideration from the FOMC board, while he added he wouldn't 'tune out' presidential pressure if nominated and that it is perfectly OK for the president to have an opinion. Furthermore, he sees a 50/50 chance of being confirmed to the position. (WSJ)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks traded subdued following a similar Wall St lead and as participants took risk off the table ahead of Easter closures
content: Asia equity markets were softer with the region tentative ahead of Easter closures and following a lacklustre performance on Wall St where a continued slump across the healthcare sector weighed across the major indices. ASX 200 (Unch) was choppy with the index initially dragged lower as health stocks tracked the underperformance of their counterparts stateside, although the index later recovered amid strength in miners and energy names following quarterly updates from the likes of Fortescue Metals, Santos and Woodside Petroleum. Meanwhile, Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) was weighed by a firmer currency, while Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) also traded subdued despite further liquidity efforts by the PBoC as hopes for a RRR cut fade and as Hong Kong participants took risk off the table ahead of a 4-day closure. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with prices supported by the cautiousness in the region and amid mild gains in T-notes, while today’s enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs also attracted greater demand.

In FX markets, the DXY is stable and just about holds on to the 97.00 level as most its major counterparts trade uneventful ahead of the upcoming holiday closures. EUR/USD is stuck near the 1.1300 level where it had been meandering throughout the week and where a large option expiry of EUR 1.4bln is also located for today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD is uneventful as the 2-week parliament recess continues to give the pair a breather from the Brexit-related chaos. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is softer amid the subdued risk tone but with downside limited as the 112.00 level continues to provide a magnet for price action, while antipodeans are relatively flat despite initial upside in AUD/USD following better than expected jobs data. The beat in headline Employment Change was solely fuelled by Full-Time workers and pushed AUD/USD to within a whisker of the 0.7200 handle, where it then met resistance as some were also kept wary by the rise in the Unemployment Rate which was one of the conditions the RBA had recently outlined for a potential rate cut. NZD/USD was quiet with interpolated OIS now pricing around 50% chance of a RBNZ rate cut in May vs. about 25% on Tuesday, although TD Securities suggests the recent CPI data is not a trigger for the RBNZ to ease as early as next month and they also see a 'solid' floor at 0.6700 for the currency.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher with prices supported by the cautiousness in the region and following mild gains in T-notes, while focus now shifts to today’s enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs.
